intro: Daucus pumilus subsp. minusculus, commonly known as the dwarf cow parsley, is a small, herbaceous plant native to southern Europe. It typically grows to a height of about 10–30 centimeters and features finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, white or pale yellow flowers arranged in umbels, which bloom in early spring. It thrives in open, sunny habitats such as grasslands and woodland edges. Its botanical characteristics make it a distinctive member of the Apiaceae family.
